			<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">2014 FIFA World Cup</h1>
									<div id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content">
									<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"><span class="mw-redirectedfrom">  (Redirected from <a href="/w/index.php?title=2014_World_Cup&amp;redirect=no" class="mw-redirect" title="2014 World Cup">2014 World Cup</a>)</span></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-head">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><div role="note" class="hatnote">"2014 World Cup" redirects here. For the official video game of the 2014 World Cup, see <a href="/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_Brazil_(video_game)" title="2014 FIFA World Cup Brazil (video game)">2014 FIFA World Cup Brazil (video game)</a>. For the basketball tournament, see <a href="/wiki/2014_FIBA_World_Cup" class="mw-redirect" title="2014 FIBA World Cup">2014 FIBA World Cup</a>.</div>

<td colspan="2" class="noprint" style="text-align:center">
<div style="float: left;">← <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2010 FIFA World Cup">2010</a></div>
<div style="float: right;"><i><a href="/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2018 FIFA World Cup">2018</a></i> →</div>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p>The <b>2014 FIFA World Cup</b> was the 20th <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup" title="FIFA World Cup">FIFA World Cup</a>, the quadrennial world championship for <a href="/wiki/List_of_men%27s_national_association_football_teams" title="List of men's national association football teams">men's national</a> <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">football</a> teams organized by <a href="/wiki/FIFA" title="FIFA">FIFA</a>. It took place in Brazil from 12 June to 13 July 2014, after the country was awarded the hosting rights in 2007. It was the second time that Brazil staged the competition (the first was in <a href="/wiki/1950_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1950 FIFA World Cup">1950</a>), and the fifth time that it was held in South America.</p>
<p>Thirty-one national teams advanced through <a href="/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification" title="2014 FIFA World Cup qualification">qualification competitions</a> to join the host nation in the final tournament. A total of 64 matches were played in 12 venues located in as many host cities across Brazil. For the first time at a World Cup finals, match officials used <a href="/wiki/Goal-line_technology" title="Goal-line technology">goal-line technology</a>, as well as <a href="/wiki/Vanishing_foam" class="mw-redirect" title="Vanishing foam">vanishing foam</a> for <a href="/wiki/Direct_free_kick" title="Direct free kick">free kicks</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-GLT_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GLT-7">[6]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/FIFA_Fan_Fest" title="FIFA Fan Fest">FIFA Fan Fests</a> in each host city gathered a total of 5 million people, and the country received 1 million visitors from 202 countries.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[7]</a></sup></p>
<p>Every World Cup-winning team since the <a href="/wiki/1930_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1930 FIFA World Cup">first edition in 1930</a> – <a href="/wiki/Argentina_national_football_team" title="Argentina national football team">Argentina</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brazil_national_football_team" title="Brazil national football team">Brazil</a>, <a href="/wiki/England_national_football_team" title="England national football team">England</a>, <a href="/wiki/France_national_football_team" title="France national football team">France</a>, <a href="/wiki/Germany_national_football_team" title="Germany national football team">Germany</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italy_national_football_team" title="Italy national football team">Italy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Spain_national_football_team" title="Spain national football team">Spain</a> and <a href="/wiki/Uruguay_national_football_team" title="Uruguay national football team">Uruguay</a> – qualified for this tournament. Spain, the title holders, were eliminated at the group stage, along with England and Italy. Uruguay were eliminated in the round of 16, and France exited in the quarter-finals. Brazil, who had won the <a href="/wiki/2013_FIFA_Confederations_Cup" title="2013 FIFA Confederations Cup">2013 FIFA Confederations Cup</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brazil_v_Germany_(2014_FIFA_World_Cup)" title="Brazil v Germany (2014 FIFA World Cup)">lost to Germany</a> 7-1 in the semi-finals and eventually finished in fourth place. In <a href="/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_Final" title="2014 FIFA World Cup Final">the final</a>, Germany defeated Argentina 1–0 to win the tournament and secure the country's fourth world title, the first after the <a href="/wiki/German_reunification" title="German reunification">German reunification</a> in 1990, when as West Germany they also beat Argentina in the <a href="/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup_Final" title="1990 FIFA World Cup Final">World Cup final</a>. Germany became the first European team to win a World Cup staged in the <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">Americas</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[8]</a></sup> and this result marked the first time that sides from the same continent had won three consecutive tournaments (following Italy in <a href="/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2006 FIFA World Cup">2006</a> and Spain in <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2010 FIFA World Cup">2010</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[9]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Trivia_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Trivia-11">[10]</a></sup></p>
<p>As the winners, Germany qualified for the <a href="/wiki/2017_FIFA_Confederations_Cup" title="2017 FIFA Confederations Cup">2017 FIFA Confederations Cup</a> in Russia.</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Host_selection">Host selection</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_bids" title="2014 FIFA World Cup bids">2014 FIFA World Cup bids</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Joseph_Blatter_-_World_Cup_2014.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Joseph_Blatter_-_World_Cup_2014.jpg/220px-Joseph_Blatter_-_World_Cup_2014.jpg" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Joseph_Blatter_-_World_Cup_2014.jpg/330px-Joseph_Blatter_-_World_Cup_2014.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Joseph_Blatter_-_World_Cup_2014.jpg/440px-Joseph_Blatter_-_World_Cup_2014.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3672" data-file-height="2458" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Joseph_Blatter_-_World_Cup_2014.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Announcing of Brazil as hosts, 2007</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>In March 2003, FIFA announced that the tournament would be held in South America for the first time since <a href="/wiki/1978_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1978 FIFA World Cup">1978</a>, in line with its then-active policy of rotating the right to host the World Cup among different confederations.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[11]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[12]</a></sup> With <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2010 FIFA World Cup">2010 FIFA World Cup</a> hosted in South Africa, it would be the second consecutive World Cup outside of Europe, which was a first for the tournament. It was also second in the Southern Hemisphere.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[13]</a></sup> Only Brazil and Colombia formally declared their candidacy but, after the withdrawal of the latter from the process,<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[14]</a></sup> Brazil was officially elected as host nation unopposed on 30 October 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[15]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Participating_teams_and_officials">Participating teams and officials</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Qualification">Qualification</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification" title="2014 FIFA World Cup qualification">2014 FIFA World Cup qualification</a></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">See also: <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_qualification" title="FIFA World Cup qualification">FIFA World Cup qualification</a></div>
<p>Following qualification matches played between June 2011 and November 2013, the following 32 teams – shown with their last pre-tournament <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Rankings" title="FIFA World Rankings">FIFA world ranking</a><sup id="cite_ref-Rankings_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rankings-17">[16]</a></sup> – qualified for the final tournament. Twenty-four of these teams were returning participants from the <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2010 FIFA World Cup">2010 World Cup</a>. <a href="/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina_national_football_team" title="Bosnia and Herzegovina national football team">Bosnia and Herzegovina</a> were the only team with no previous appearance at the World Cup finals.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[nb 2]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[17]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Colombia_national_football_team" title="Colombia national football team">Colombia</a> qualified for the World Cup after <a href="/wiki/1998_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1998 FIFA World Cup">16 years of absence</a>, while <a href="/wiki/Russia_national_football_team" title="Russia national football team">Russia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Belgium_national_football_team" title="Belgium national football team">Belgium</a> returned after 12 years. The highest ranked team to not qualify was <a href="/wiki/Ukraine_national_football_team" title="Ukraine national football team">Ukraine</a> (ranked 16th), while the lowest ranked team that did qualify was <a href="/wiki/Australia_national_football_team" class="mw-redirect" title="Australia national football team">Australia</a> (ranked 62nd).<sup id="cite_ref-Rankings_17-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rankings-17">[16]</a></sup></p>
<div>
<table class="multicol" role="presentation" style="border-collapse: collapse; padding: 0; border: 0; background:transparent; width:100%;">
<tr>
<td style="width:25%;text-align:left;vertical-align:top;">

<li><span style="white-space:nowrap"><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Flag_of_Iran.svg/23px-Flag_of_Iran.svg.png" width="23" height="13" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Flag_of_Iran.svg/35px-Flag_of_Iran.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Flag_of_Iran.svg/46px-Flag_of_Iran.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="630" data-file-height="360" />&#160;</span><a href="/wiki/Iran_national_football_team" title="Iran national football team">Iran</a></span> (43)</li>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Final_draw">Final draw</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_seeding" title="2014 FIFA World Cup seeding">2014 FIFA World Cup seeding</a></div>
<p>The 32 participating teams were drawn into eight groups. In preparation for this, the teams were organised into four pots with the seven <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Rankings" title="FIFA World Rankings">highest-ranked</a> teams joining host nation <a href="/wiki/Brazil_national_football_team" title="Brazil national football team">Brazil</a> in the seeded pot.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[18]</a></sup> As with the previous tournaments, FIFA aimed to create groups which maximised geographic separation and therefore the unseeded teams were arranged into pots based on geographic considerations.<sup id="cite_ref-Draw_procedures_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Draw_procedures-21">[19]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[20]</a></sup> The draw took place on 6 December 2013 at the Costa do Sauípe resort in <a href="/wiki/Bahia" title="Bahia">Bahia</a>, during which the teams were drawn by various past World Cup-winning players.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[21]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[22]</a></sup> Under the draw procedure, one randomly drawn team – Italy – was firstly relocated from Pot 4 to Pot 2 to create four equal pots of eight teams.<sup id="cite_ref-Draw_procedures_21-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Draw_procedures-21">[19]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Officials">Officials</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_officials" title="2014 FIFA World Cup officials">2014 FIFA World Cup officials</a></div>
<p>In March 2013, FIFA published a list of 52 prospective referees, each paired, on the basis of nationality, with two <a href="/wiki/Assistant_referee_(association_football)" title="Assistant referee (association football)">assistant referees</a>, from all six football confederations for the tournament. On 14 January 2014, the FIFA Referees Committee appointed 25 referee trios and eight support duos representing 43 different countries for the tournament.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[23]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[24]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Yuichi_Nishimura" title="Yuichi Nishimura">Yuichi Nishimura</a> from <a href="/wiki/Japan_Football_Association" title="Japan Football Association">Japan</a> acted as referee in the opening match whereas <a href="/wiki/Nicola_Rizzoli" title="Nicola Rizzoli">Nicola Rizzoli</a> from <a href="/wiki/Italian_Football_Federation" title="Italian Football Federation">Italy</a> acted as referee in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-Matches_1-4_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Matches_1-4-27">[25]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[26]</a></sup></p>
<table class="wikitable collapsible collapsed">
<tr>
<th colspan="5">List of officials</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<th>Confederation</th>
<th>Referee</th>
<th colspan="2">Assistants</th>
<th>Support (referee/assist)</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td rowspan="4"><a href="/wiki/Asian_Football_Confederation" title="Asian Football Confederation">AFC</a></td>
<td><a href="/wiki/Ravshan_Irmatov" title="Ravshan Irmatov">Ravshan Irmatov</a> (<a href="/wiki/Uzbekistan_Football_Federation" title="Uzbekistan Football Federation">Uzbekistan</a>)</td>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Squads">Squads</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_squads" title="2014 FIFA World Cup squads">2014 FIFA World Cup squads</a></div>
<p>As with the <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_squads" title="2010 FIFA World Cup squads">2010 tournament</a>, each team's squad consists of 23 players (three of whom must be goalkeepers). Each participating national association had to confirm their final 23-player squad no later than 10 days before the start of the tournament.<sup id="cite_ref-regulations_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-regulations-29">[27]</a></sup> Teams were permitted to make late replacements in the event of serious injury, at any time up to 24 hours before their first game.<sup id="cite_ref-regulations_29-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-regulations-29">[27]</a></sup> During a match, all remaining squad members not named in the starting team are available to be one of the three permitted substitutions (provided the player is not serving a suspension).<sup id="cite_ref-regulations_29-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-regulations-29">[27]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Venues">Venues</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_venues" title="2014 FIFA World Cup venues">2014 FIFA World Cup venues</a></div>
<p>12 venues (seven new and five renovated) in twelve cities were selected for the tournament. The venues covered all the main <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_Brazil" title="Regions of Brazil">regions of Brazil</a> and created more evenly distributed hosting than the <a href="/wiki/1950_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1950 FIFA World Cup">1950 finals</a> in Brazil.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[28]</a></sup> Consequently, the tournament required long-distance travel for teams.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[29]</a></sup> During the World Cup, Brazilian cities were also home to the participating teams at <a href="/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_venues#Team_base_camps" title="2014 FIFA World Cup venues">32 separate base camps</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-32">[30]</a></sup> as well as staging <a href="/wiki/FIFA_Fan_Fest#2014" title="FIFA Fan Fest">official fan fests</a> where supporters could view the games.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[31]</a></sup></p>
<center>

</center>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Team_base_camps">Team base camps</span></h3>
<p>Base camps were used by the 32 national squads to stay and train before and during the World Cup tournament. On 31 January 2014, FIFA announced the base camps for each participating team,<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_32-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-32">[30]</a></sup> having earlier circulated a brochure of 84 prospective locations.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[33]</a></sup> Most teams opted to stay in the <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Region,_Brazil" title="Southeast Region, Brazil">Southeast Region</a> of Brazil, with only eight teams choosing other regions; five teams (Croatia, Germany, Ghana, Greece and Switzerland) opted to stay in the <a href="/wiki/Northeast_Region,_Brazil" title="Northeast Region, Brazil">Northeast Region</a> and three teams (Ecuador, South Korea and Spain) opted to stay in the <a href="/wiki/South_Region,_Brazil" title="South Region, Brazil">South Region</a>. None opted to stay in the <a href="/wiki/North_Region,_Brazil" title="North Region, Brazil">North Region</a> or the <a href="/wiki/Central-West_Region,_Brazil" title="Central-West Region, Brazil">Central-West Region</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[34]</a></sup></p>
<table class="wikitable collapsible collapsed">

</div>
</div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="FIFA_Fan_Fests">FIFA Fan Fests</span></h3>
<p>For a third consecutive World Cup tournament, FIFA staged <a href="/wiki/FIFA_Fan_Fest" title="FIFA Fan Fest">FIFA Fan Fests</a> in each of the 12 host cities throughout the competition. Prominent examples were the <a href="/wiki/Copacabana_Beach" class="mw-redirect" title="Copacabana Beach">Copacabana Beach</a> in Rio de Janeiro, which already held a Fan Fest in 2010, and <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="São Paulo">São Paulo</a>'s Vale do Anhangabaú.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[35]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[36]</a></sup> The first official event took place on <a href="/wiki/Praia_de_Iracema" title="Praia de Iracema">Iracema Beach</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Fortaleza" title="Fortaleza">Fortaleza</a>, on 8 June 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[37]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Innovations">Innovations</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Technologies">Technologies</span></h3>
<p>To avoid <a href="/wiki/Ghost_goal" title="Ghost goal">ghost goals</a> the 2014 World Cup introduced <a href="/wiki/Goal-line_technology" title="Goal-line technology">goal-line technology</a> following successful trials at among others <a href="/wiki/2013_FIFA_Confederations_Cup" title="2013 FIFA Confederations Cup">2013 Confederations Cup</a>. The chosen <a href="/wiki/GoalControl" title="GoalControl">Goal Control system</a> featured 14 high speed cameras, 7 directed to each of the goals. Data were sent to the central image-processing centre, where a virtual representation of the ball was output on a widescreen to confirm the goal. The referee was equipped with a watch which vibrated and displayed a signal upon a goal.<sup id="cite_ref-DW_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DW-41">[38]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Yah_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Yah-42">[39]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-TR_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TR-43">[40]</a></sup> France's second goal in their <a href="/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_E#France_vs_Honduras" title="2014 FIFA World Cup Group E">group game</a> against Honduras was the first time goal-line technology was needed to confirm that a goal should be given.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[41]</a></sup></p>
<p>Following successful trials,<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[nb 4]</a></sup> FIFA approved the use of <a href="/wiki/Vanishing_foam" class="mw-redirect" title="Vanishing foam">vanishing foam</a> by the referees for the first time at a World Cup Finals. The water-based spray, which disappears within minutes of application, can be used to mark a ten-yard line for the defending team during a <a href="/wiki/Direct_free_kick" title="Direct free kick">free kick</a> and also to draw where the ball is to be placed for a free kick.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[42]</a></sup></p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Adidas" title="Adidas">Adidas</a> <a href="/wiki/Adidas_Brazuca" title="Adidas Brazuca">Brazuca</a> was the official <a href="/wiki/Football_(association_football)" class="mw-redirect" title="Football (association football)">match ball</a> of the 2014 FIFA World Cup<sup id="cite_ref-forbes_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-forbes-47">[43]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-brazucafifanews_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-brazucafifanews-48">[44]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-brazucaadidasgroup_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-brazucaadidasgroup-49">[45]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-brazucafifamatchball_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-brazucafifamatchball-50">[46]</a></sup> and was supplied by <a href="/wiki/Forward_Sports" title="Forward Sports">Forward Sports</a> of <a href="/wiki/Sialkot" title="Sialkot">Sialkot</a>, Pakistan.<sup id="cite_ref-forbes_47-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-forbes-47">[43]</a></sup> Adidas created a new design of ball after criticisms of the <a href="/wiki/Adidas_Jabulani" title="Adidas Jabulani">Adidas Jabulani</a> used in the <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2010 FIFA World Cup">previous World Cup</a>. The number of panels was reduced to six, with the panels being thermally bonded. This created a ball with increased consistency and aerodynamics compared to its predecessor. Furthermore, Adidas underwent an extensive testing process lasting more than two years to produce a ball that would meet the approval of football professionals.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cooling_breaks">Cooling breaks</span></h3>
<p>Because of the relatively high ambient temperatures in Brazil, particularly at the northern venues, cooling breaks for the players were introduced.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[47]</a></sup> Breaks could take place at the referee's discretion after the 30th minute of each half if the <a href="/wiki/Wet_Bulb_Globe_Temperature" class="mw-redirect" title="Wet Bulb Globe Temperature">Wet Bulb Globe Temperature</a> exceeded 32&#160;°C (90&#160;°F).</p>
<p>The first cooling break in World Cup play took place during the 32nd minute of the <a href="/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_knockout_stage#Netherlands_vs_Mexico" title="2014 FIFA World Cup knockout stage">match between the Netherlands and Mexico in the round of 16</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[48]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[49]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[50]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[51]</a></sup> At the start of the match, FIFA listed the temperature at 32&#160;°C (90&#160;°F) with 68% humidity.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[52]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Anti-doping">Anti-doping</span></h3>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Biological_passport" title="Biological passport">biological passport</a> was introduced in the FIFA World Cup starting in 2014. <a href="/wiki/Blood" title="Blood">Blood</a> and <a href="/wiki/Urine" title="Urine">urine</a> samples from all players before the competition, and from two players per team per match, are analysed by the <a href="/wiki/Swiss_Laboratory_for_Doping_Analyses" title="Swiss Laboratory for Doping Analyses">Swiss Laboratory for Doping Analyses</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[53]</a></sup> FIFA reported that 91.5% of the players taking part in the tournament were tested before the start of the competition and none tested positive.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[54]</a></sup> However, FIFA was criticised for its approach towards finding doping offences.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify"><span title="The text near this tag may need clarification or removal of jargon. (June 2014)">clarification needed</span></a></i>]</sup><sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[55]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[56]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Format">Format</span></h2>
<p><span id="Tie-breaking_criteria"></span> The first round, or group stage, was a competition between the 32 teams divided among eight groups of four, where each group engaged in a <a href="/wiki/Round-robin_tournament" title="Round-robin tournament">round-robin tournament</a> within itself. The two highest ranked teams in each group advanced to the knockout stage.<sup id="cite_ref-regulations_29-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-regulations-29">[27]</a></sup> Teams were awarded three points for a win and one for a draw. When comparing teams in a group over-all result came before head-to-head.</p>
<table class="wikitable collapsible collapsed">
<tr>
<th>Tie-breaking criteria for group play</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>The ranking of teams in each group was based on the following criteria:
<ol>
<li>Number of points</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Goal_difference" title="Goal difference">Goal difference</a></li>
<li>Number of goals scored</li>
<li>Number of points obtained in matches between tied teams</li>
<li>Goal difference in matches between tied teams</li>
<li>Number of goals scored in matches between tied teams</li>
<li>Drawing of lots</li>
</ol>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p>In the <a href="/wiki/Single-elimination_tournament" title="Single-elimination tournament">knockout stage</a> there were four rounds (round of 16, quarter-finals, semi-finals, and the final), with each eliminating the losers. The two semi-final losers competed in a third place play-off. For any match in the knockout stage, a draw after 90 minutes of regulation time was followed by two 15 minute periods of <a href="/wiki/Overtime_(association_football)" class="mw-redirect" title="Overtime (association football)">extra time</a> to determine a winner. If the teams were still tied, a <a href="/wiki/Penalty_shoot-out_(association_football)" title="Penalty shoot-out (association football)">penalty shoot-out</a> was held to determine a winner.<sup id="cite_ref-regulations_29-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-regulations-29">[27]</a></sup></p>
<p>The match schedule was announced on 20 October 2011<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[57]</a></sup> with the kick-off times being confirmed on 27 September 2012;<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[58]</a></sup> after the final draw, the kick-off times of seven matches were adjusted by FIFA.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[59]</a></sup> The competition was organised so that teams that played each other in the group stage could not meet again during the knockout phase until the final (or the 3rd place match).<sup id="cite_ref-regulations_29-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-regulations-29">[27]</a></sup> The group stage began on 12 June, with the host nation competing in the opening game as has been the format since the 2006 tournament. The opening game was preceded by an <a href="/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_opening_ceremony" title="2014 FIFA World Cup opening ceremony">opening ceremony</a> that began at 15:15 local time.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[60]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Match_summary">Match summary</span></h2>
<p>The 32 teams played a total of 64 matches which included 48 group stage matches, eight round of 16 matches, four quarter-final matches, two semi-finals, a match to decide third place and the <a href="/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_Final" title="2014 FIFA World Cup Final">final</a> match. Rest days were allocated during the various stages to allow players recovery during the tournament.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[61]</a></sup> All times listed in the table below are in <a href="/wiki/Time_in_Brazil#Bras.C3.ADlia_official_time_-_BRT_.28UTC-03.29" title="Time in Brazil">Brasília official time</a> (<a href="/wiki/UTC%E2%88%9203:00" title="UTC−03:00">UTC−3</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[nb 5]</a></sup></p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Results">Results</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Group_stage">Group stage</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_group_stage" title="2014 FIFA World Cup group stage">2014 FIFA World Cup group stage</a></div>
<p>The <b>group stage of the 2014 FIFA World Cup</b> took place in <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a> from 12 June 2014 to 26 June 2014: each team played three games. The group stage was notable for a scarcity of draws and a large number of goals. The first drawn (and goalless) match did not occur until the 13th match of the tournament, between Iran and Nigeria: a drought longer than any World Cup since 1930.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[67]</a></sup> The group stage produced a total of 136 goals (an average of 2.83 goals per match), nine fewer than were scored during the entire 2010 tournament.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[68]</a></sup> This is the largest number of goals in the group stage since the 32-team system was implemented in 1998<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[69]</a></sup> and the largest average in a group stage since 1958.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[70]</a></sup> World Cup holders Spain were eliminated after only two games, the quickest exit for the defending champions since Italy's from the <a href="/wiki/1950_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1950 FIFA World Cup">1950 tournament</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[71]</a></sup> Spain also became the fourth nation to be eliminated in the first round while holding the World Cup crown, the first one being Italy in 1950 (and again in 2010), the second Brazil in 1966, and the third France in 2002.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[72]</a></sup></p>

<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Group_G">Group G</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_G" title="2014 FIFA World Cup Group G">2014 FIFA World Cup Group G</a></div>
<table class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;">
<tr>
<th scope="col" width="28"><abbr title="Position">Pos</abbr></th>
<th scope="col" width="200">Team
<div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini" style="float:right">

<p><br />
Scores after extra time are indicated by (aet), and penalty shoot-outs are indicated by (pen.).</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Round_of_16">Round of 16</span></h4>
<p>For the first time since the introduction of a round of 16 after the group stage in 1986, all the group winners advanced into the quarter-finals.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[73]</a></sup> They included four teams from UEFA, three from CONMEBOL, and one from CONCACAF. Of the eight matches, five required extra-time, and two of these <a href="/wiki/List_of_FIFA_World_Cup_penalty_shoot-outs" title="List of FIFA World Cup penalty shoot-outs">required penalty shoot-outs</a>; this was the first time penalty shoot-outs happened in more than one game in a round of 16.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[nb 6]</a></sup> The goal average per game in the round of 16 was 2.25, a drop of 0.58 goals per game from the group stage.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[74]</a></sup> The eight teams to win in the round of 16 included four former champions (Brazil, Germany, Argentina and France), a three-time runner-up (Netherlands), and two first-time quarter-finalists (Colombia and Costa Rica).<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[75]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[76]</a></sup> Belgium reached the quarter-finals for the first time since 1986.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[77]</a></sup></p>
<p><i>All times listed below are at local time (<a href="/wiki/UTC%E2%88%9203:00" title="UTC−03:00">UTC−3</a>)</i></p>
<div style="width: 100%; background-color: transparent; clear:both" class="vevent">

<div style="clear:both;"></div>
</div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Quarter-finals">Quarter-finals</span></h4>
<p>With a 1–0 victory over France, Germany set a World Cup record with four consecutive semi-final appearances. Brazil beat Colombia 2–1, but Brazil's <a href="/wiki/Neymar" title="Neymar">Neymar</a> was injured and missed the rest of the competition. Argentina reached the final four for the first time since 1990 after a 1–0 win over Belgium. The Netherlands reached the semi-finals for the second consecutive tournament, after overcoming Costa Rica in a <a href="/wiki/Penalty_shootout_(football)" class="mw-redirect" title="Penalty shootout (football)">penalty shoot-out</a> following a 0–0 draw at the end of extra time.</p>
<div style="width: 100%; background-color: transparent; clear:both" class="vevent">

<td style="text-align:right"><a href="/wiki/Robin_van_Persie" title="Robin van Persie">Van Persie</a> <img alt="Penalty scored" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Soccerball_shad_check.svg/13px-Soccerball_shad_check.svg.png" title="Penalty scored" width="13" height="13" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Soccerball_shad_check.svg/20px-Soccerball_shad_check.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Soccerball_shad_check.svg/26px-Soccerball_shad_check.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="313" data-file-height="313" /><br />

<a href="/wiki/Dirk_Kuyt" title="Dirk Kuyt">Kuyt</a> <img alt="Penalty scored" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Soccerball_shad_check.svg/13px-Soccerball_shad_check.svg.png" title="Penalty scored" width="13" height="13" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Soccerball_shad_check.svg/20px-Soccerball_shad_check.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Soccerball_shad_check.svg/26px-Soccerball_shad_check.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="313" data-file-height="313" /></td>
<th style="text-align:center">4–3</th>
<td style="text-align:left"><img alt="Penalty scored" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Soccerball_shad_check.svg/13px-Soccerball_shad_check.svg.png" title="Penalty scored" width="13" height="13" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Soccerball_shad_check.svg/20px-Soccerball_shad_check.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Soccerball_shad_check.svg/26px-Soccerball_shad_check.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="313" data-file-height="313" /> <a href="/wiki/Celso_Borges" title="Celso Borges">Borges</a><br />

Attendance: 51,179<br />
Referee: <a href="/wiki/Ravshan_Irmatov" title="Ravshan Irmatov">Ravshan Irmatov</a> (<a href="/wiki/Uzbekistan_Football_Federation" title="Uzbekistan Football Federation">Uzbekistan</a>)</div>

<div style="clear:both;"></div>

<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Semi-finals">Semi-finals</span></h4>
<p>Germany qualified for the final for the eighth time with a <a href="/wiki/Brazil_v_Germany_(2014_FIFA_World_Cup)" title="Brazil v Germany (2014 FIFA World Cup)">7–1 win over Brazil</a> – the biggest defeat in Brazilian history since 1920. <a href="/wiki/Miroslav_Klose" title="Miroslav Klose">Miroslav Klose</a>'s goal in this match was his 16th throughout all World Cups, breaking the record he had previously shared with <a href="/wiki/Ronaldo" title="Ronaldo">Ronaldo</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[78]</a></sup> Klose set another record by becoming the first player to appear in four World Cup semi-finals.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[79]</a></sup> Argentina reached their first final since 1990, and the fifth overall after overcoming the Netherlands in a <a href="/wiki/Penalty_shoot-out_(association_football)" title="Penalty shoot-out (association football)">penalty shoot-out</a> following a 0–0 draw at the end of extra time.</p>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Brazil_v_Germany_(2014_FIFA_World_Cup)" title="Brazil v Germany (2014 FIFA World Cup)">Brazil v Germany (2014 FIFA World Cup)</a></div>
<div style="width: 100%; background-color: transparent; clear:both" class="vevent">
<p><span class="summary" style="display: none;"><a href="/wiki/Brazil_national_football_team" title="Brazil national football team">Brazil</a><span class="flagicon">&#160;<img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/05/Flag_of_Brazil.svg/22px-Flag_of_Brazil.svg.png" width="22" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/05/Flag_of_Brazil.svg/33px-Flag_of_Brazil.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/05/Flag_of_Brazil.svg/43px-Flag_of_Brazil.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="720" data-file-height="504" /></span> v <span style="white-space:nowrap"><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Germany.svg/23px-Flag_of_Germany.svg.png" width="23" height="14" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Germany.svg/35px-Flag_of_Germany.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Germany.svg/46px-Flag_of_Germany.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="600" />&#160;</span><a href="/wiki/Germany_national_football_team" title="Germany national football team">Germany</a></span></span></p>

<tr>
<td>
<div style="font-size: 85%"><span class="location"><a href="/wiki/Arena_Corinthians" title="Arena Corinthians">Arena de São Paulo</a>, <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="São Paulo">São Paulo</a></span><br />
Attendance: 63,267<br />
Referee: <a href="/wiki/C%C3%BCneyt_%C3%87ak%C4%B1r" title="Cüneyt Çakır">Cüneyt Çakır</a> (<a href="/wiki/Turkish_Football_Federation" title="Turkish Football Federation">Turkey</a>)</div>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
</div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Third_place_play-off">Third place play-off</span></h4>
<p>The Netherlands defeated Brazil 3–0 to secure third place, the first for the Dutch team in their history. Overall, Brazil conceded 14 goals in the tournament; this was the most by a team at any single World Cup since 1986, and the most by a host nation in history, although their fourth-place finish still represented Brazil's best result in a World Cup since their last win in 2002.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[80]</a></sup></p>
<div style="width: 100%; background-color: transparent; clear:both" class="vevent">
<p><span class="summary" style="display: none;"><a href="/wiki/Brazil_national_football_team" title="Brazil national football team">Brazil</a><span class="flagicon">&#160;<img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/05/Flag_of_Brazil.svg/22px-Flag_of_Brazil.svg.png" width="22" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/05/Flag_of_Brazil.svg/33px-Flag_of_Brazil.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/05/Flag_of_Brazil.svg/43px-Flag_of_Brazil.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="720" data-file-height="504" /></span> v <span style="white-space:nowrap"><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg.png" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg/45px-Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="900" data-file-height="600" />&#160;</span><a href="/wiki/Netherlands_national_football_team" title="Netherlands national football team">Netherlands</a></span></span></p>

<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Final">Final</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_Final" title="2014 FIFA World Cup Final">2014 FIFA World Cup Final</a></div>
<p>The final featured Germany against Argentina for a record third time after 1986 and 1990.</p>
<div style="width: 100%; background-color: transparent; clear:both" class="vevent">
<p><span class="summary" style="display: none;"><a href="/wiki/Germany_national_football_team" title="Germany national football team">Germany</a><span class="flagicon">&#160;<img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Germany.svg/23px-Flag_of_Germany.svg.png" width="23" height="14" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Germany.svg/35px-Flag_of_Germany.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Germany.svg/46px-Flag_of_Germany.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="600" /></span> v <span style="white-space:nowrap"><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Flag_of_Argentina.svg/23px-Flag_of_Argentina.svg.png" width="23" height="14" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Flag_of_Argentina.svg/35px-Flag_of_Argentina.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Flag_of_Argentina.svg/46px-Flag_of_Argentina.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="500" />&#160;</span><a href="/wiki/Argentina_national_football_team" title="Argentina national football team">Argentina</a></span></span></p>
<table style="float:left; width:15%; table-layout:fixed">
<tr>
<td>
<div style="text-align:right">13 July 2014<br />
16:00<br /></div>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table style="float:left; width:61%; table-layout:fixed; text-align:center">
<tr style="vertical-align:top">

<table style="float:left; width:24%; table-layout:fixed">
<tr>
<td>
<div style="font-size: 85%"><span class="location"><a href="/wiki/Est%C3%A1dio_do_Maracan%C3%A3" class="mw-redirect" title="Estádio do Maracanã">Estádio do Maracanã</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a></span><br />
Attendance: 74,738<br />
Referee: <a href="/wiki/Nicola_Rizzoli" title="Nicola Rizzoli">Nicola Rizzoli</a> (<a href="/wiki/Italian_Football_Federation" title="Italian Football Federation">Italy</a>)</div>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
</div>
<p>This marked the first time that teams from the same continent had won three consecutive World Cups (following Italy in <a href="/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2006 FIFA World Cup">2006</a> and Spain in <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2010 FIFA World Cup">2010</a>). It was also the first time that a European nation had won the World Cup in the Americas. On aggregate Europe now has 11 victories, compared to South America's 9 victories.</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Statistics">Statistics</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_statistics" title="2014 FIFA World Cup statistics">2014 FIFA World Cup statistics</a></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">See also: <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_records" class="mw-redirect" title="FIFA World Cup records">FIFA World Cup records</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Goalscorers">Goalscorers</span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/James_Rodr%C3%ADguez" title="James Rodríguez">James Rodríguez</a> was awarded the <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_awards#Golden_Boot" title="FIFA World Cup awards">Golden Boot</a> for scoring six goals, the first time that a Colombian player received the award. In total, 171 goals were scored by a record 121 players, with five credited as own goals. Goals scored from <a href="/wiki/Penalty_shoot-out_(association_football)" title="Penalty shoot-out (association football)">penalty shoot-outs</a> are not counted.</p>
<dl>
<dt>6 goals</dt>
</dl>
<ul>
<li><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia"><img alt="Colombia" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Flag_of_Colombia.svg/23px-Flag_of_Colombia.svg.png" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Flag_of_Colombia.svg/35px-Flag_of_Colombia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Flag_of_Colombia.svg/45px-Flag_of_Colombia.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="450" data-file-height="300" /></a></span> <a href="/wiki/James_Rodr%C3%ADguez" title="James Rodríguez">James Rodríguez</a></li>
</ul>
<dl>

</dl>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Assists">Assists</span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Juan_Cuadrado" title="Juan Cuadrado">Juan Cuadrado</a> and <a href="/wiki/Toni_Kroos" title="Toni Kroos">Toni Kroos</a> finished highest in the assists table with four assists each.</p>

<p><small>Source: UEFA</small><sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[82]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Discipline">Discipline</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_disciplinary_record" title="2014 FIFA World Cup disciplinary record">2014 FIFA World Cup disciplinary record</a></div>
<p>The most notable disciplinary case was that of Uruguayan striker <a href="/wiki/Luis_Su%C3%A1rez" title="Luis Suárez">Luis Suárez</a>, who <a href="/wiki/Luis_Su%C3%A1rez_controversies" title="Luis Suárez controversies">was suspended for nine international matches and banned from taking part in any football-related activity</a> (including entering any stadium) for four months, following a <a href="/wiki/List_of_2014_FIFA_World_Cup_controversies#Uruguay_vs_Italy" title="List of 2014 FIFA World Cup controversies">biting incident</a> on Italian defender <a href="/wiki/Giorgio_Chiellini" title="Giorgio Chiellini">Giorgio Chiellini</a>. He was also fined <a href="/wiki/Swiss_franc" title="Swiss franc">CHF</a>100,000.<sup id="cite_ref-Suarez_suspension_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Suarez_suspension-89">[83]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ban2014_90-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ban2014-90">[84]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Luis_Suarez_suspended_91-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Luis_Suarez_suspended-91">[85]</a></sup> After an appeal to the <a href="/wiki/Court_of_Arbitration_for_Sport" title="Court of Arbitration for Sport">Court of Arbitration for Sport</a>, Suárez was later allowed to participate in training and friendly matches with new club <a href="/wiki/FC_Barcelona" title="FC Barcelona">Barcelona</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[86]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Awards">Awards</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_awards" title="2014 FIFA World Cup awards">2014 FIFA World Cup awards</a></div>
<p>The following awards were given at the conclusion of the tournament:<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[87]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[88]</a></sup></p>
<table class="wikitable">
<tr>
<th>Award</th>
<th>Winner</th>
<th>Other nominees</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="/wiki/Golden_Ball_(FIFA)" class="mw-redirect" title="Golden Ball (FIFA)">Golden Ball</a></td>
<td valign="top">
<p><span style="display:none;" class="sortkey">01 !</span><span class="sorttext"><img alt="1st, gold medalist(s)" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Gold_medal_icon.svg/16px-Gold_medal_icon.svg.png" width="16" height="16" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Gold_medal_icon.svg/24px-Gold_medal_icon.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Gold_medal_icon.svg/32px-Gold_medal_icon.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="16" data-file-height="16" /></span> <span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina"><img alt="Argentina" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Flag_of_Argentina.svg/23px-Flag_of_Argentina.svg.png" width="23" height="14" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Flag_of_Argentina.svg/35px-Flag_of_Argentina.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Flag_of_Argentina.svg/46px-Flag_of_Argentina.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="500" /></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Lionel_Messi" title="Lionel Messi">Lionel Messi</a><br />

<td valign="top">

<dl>
<dt>Technical Study Group</dt>
</dl>
<p>The members of the Technical Study Group, the committee that decided which players won the awards, were led by FIFA's head of the Technical Division <a href="/wiki/Jean-Paul_Brigger" title="Jean-Paul Brigger">Jean-Paul Brigger</a> and featured:<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[93]</a></sup></p>
<div>
<table class="multicol" role="presentation" style="border-collapse: collapse; padding: 0; border: 0; background:transparent; width:100%;">
<tr>
<td style="width: 33.33%;text-align:left;vertical-align:top;">
<ul>
<li><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/France" title="France"><img alt="France" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c3/Flag_of_France.svg/23px-Flag_of_France.svg.png" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c3/Flag_of_France.svg/35px-Flag_of_France.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c3/Flag_of_France.svg/45px-Flag_of_France.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="900" data-file-height="600" /></a></span> <a href="/wiki/G%C3%A9rard_Houllier" title="Gérard Houllier">Gérard Houllier</a></li>

<li><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong"><img alt="Hong Kong" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Flag_of_Hong_Kong.svg/23px-Flag_of_Hong_Kong.svg.png" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Flag_of_Hong_Kong.svg/35px-Flag_of_Hong_Kong.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Flag_of_Hong_Kong.svg/45px-Flag_of_Hong_Kong.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="900" data-file-height="600" /></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Kwok_Ka_Ming" title="Kwok Ka Ming">Kwok Ka Ming</a></li>

<li><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain"><img alt="Spain" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9a/Flag_of_Spain.svg/23px-Flag_of_Spain.svg.png" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9a/Flag_of_Spain.svg/35px-Flag_of_Spain.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9a/Flag_of_Spain.svg/45px-Flag_of_Spain.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="750" data-file-height="500" /></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Gin%C3%A9s_Mel%C3%A9ndez" title="Ginés Meléndez">Ginés Meléndez</a></li>
<li><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan"><img alt="Japan" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9e/Flag_of_Japan.svg/23px-Flag_of_Japan.svg.png" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9e/Flag_of_Japan.svg/35px-Flag_of_Japan.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9e/Flag_of_Japan.svg/45px-Flag_of_Japan.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="900" data-file-height="600" /></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Tsuneyasu_Miyamoto" title="Tsuneyasu Miyamoto">Tsuneyasu Miyamoto</a></li>

</ul>
</td>
<td style="width: 33.33%;text-align:left;vertical-align:top;">
<ul>
<li><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/Finland" title="Finland"><img alt="Finland" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Flag_of_Finland.svg/23px-Flag_of_Finland.svg.png" width="23" height="14" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Flag_of_Finland.svg/35px-Flag_of_Finland.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Flag_of_Finland.svg/46px-Flag_of_Finland.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1800" data-file-height="1100" /></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Mixu_Paatelainen" title="Mixu Paatelainen">Mixu Paatelainen</a></li>
<li><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/El_Salvador" title="El Salvador"><img alt="El Salvador" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Flag_of_El_Salvador.svg/23px-Flag_of_El_Salvador.svg.png" width="23" height="13" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Flag_of_El_Salvador.svg/35px-Flag_of_El_Salvador.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Flag_of_El_Salvador.svg/46px-Flag_of_El_Salvador.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1064" data-file-height="600" /></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Jaime_Rodr%C3%ADguez" title="Jaime Rodríguez">Jaime Rodríguez</a></li>
<li><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/Jamaica" title="Jamaica"><img alt="Jamaica" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Flag_of_Jamaica.svg/23px-Flag_of_Jamaica.svg.png" width="23" height="12" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Flag_of_Jamaica.svg/35px-Flag_of_Jamaica.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Flag_of_Jamaica.svg/46px-Flag_of_Jamaica.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="600" data-file-height="300" /></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Theodore_Whitmore" title="Theodore Whitmore">Theodore Whitmore</a></li>
</ul>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</div>
<p>There were changes to the voting procedure for awards for the 2014 edition: while in 2010 accredited media were allowed to vote for the Golden Ball award,<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[94]</a></sup> in 2014 only the Technical Study Group could select the outcome.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[95]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Dream_Team">Dream Team</span></h3>
<p>As was the case during the 2010 edition, FIFA did not release an official <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_awards#All-Star_Team" title="FIFA World Cup awards">All-Star Team</a>, but instead invited users of FIFA.com to elect their Dream Team.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[96]</a></sup></p>

</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p><a href="/wiki/Castrol" title="Castrol">Castrol</a>, the official sponsor of the tournament, released a team of the tournament based on their <a href="/wiki/Castrol_Performance_Index" title="Castrol Performance Index">Castrol Performance Index</a>, which evaluates player performances through statistical data. The team consisted of the players leading each position, with midfielder <a href="/wiki/Toni_Kroos" title="Toni Kroos">Toni Kroos</a> ranked as the overall leader.<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[97]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Lionel_Messi" title="Lionel Messi">Lionel Messi</a>, the Golden Ball recipient, finished fifth among forwards and was thus not included in the team.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[98]</a></sup></p>

</td>
<td valign="top">
<p><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/Netherlands" title="Netherlands"><img alt="Netherlands" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg.png" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg/45px-Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="900" data-file-height="600" /></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Arjen_Robben" title="Arjen Robben">Arjen Robben</a> (<a href="/wiki/Netherlands_national_football_team" title="Netherlands national football team">Netherlands</a>)<br />
<span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany"><img alt="Germany" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Germany.svg/23px-Flag_of_Germany.svg.png" width="23" height="14" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Germany.svg/35px-Flag_of_Germany.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Germany.svg/46px-Flag_of_Germany.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="600" /></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Thomas_M%C3%BCller" title="Thomas Müller">Thomas Müller</a> (<a href="/wiki/Germany_national_football_team" title="Germany national football team">Germany</a>)</p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prize_money">Prize money</span></h3>
<p>The total prize money on offer for the tournament was confirmed by FIFA as <a href="/wiki/United_States_dollar" title="United States dollar">US</a>$576 million (including payments of $70 million to domestic clubs and $100 million as player insurances), a 37 percent increase from the amount <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup#Prize_money" title="2010 FIFA World Cup">allocated in the 2010 tournament</a>. Before the tournament, each of the 32 entrants received $1.5 million for preparation costs. At the tournament, the prize money was distributed as follows:<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_105-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-105">[99]</a></sup></p>
<ul>
<li>$8 million – To each team eliminated at the <a href="#Group_stage">group stage</a> (16 teams)</li>
<li>$9 million – To each team eliminated in the <a href="#Round_of_16">round of 16</a> (8 teams)</li>
<li>$14 million – To each team eliminated in the <a href="#Quarter-finals">quarter-finals</a> (4 teams)</li>
<li>$20 million – <a href="#Third_place_play-off">Fourth placed team</a></li>
<li>$22 million – <a href="#Third_place_play-off">Third placed team</a></li>
<li>$25 million – <a href="#Final">Runner-up</a></li>
<li>$35 million – <a href="#Final">Winner</a></li>
</ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tournament_team_rankings">Tournament team rankings</span></h3>
<p><small>Note: As per statistical convention in football, matches decided in <a href="/wiki/Extra_time_(association_football)" class="mw-redirect" title="Extra time (association football)">extra time</a> are counted as wins and losses, while matches decided by <a href="/wiki/Penalty_shoot-out_(association_football)" title="Penalty shoot-out (association football)">penalty shoot-outs</a> are counted as draws.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[100]</a></sup></small></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:442px;"><a href="/wiki/File:2014_FIFA_World_Cup_Map.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_Map.svg/440px-2014_FIFA_World_Cup_Map.svg.png" width="440" height="189" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_Map.svg/660px-2014_FIFA_World_Cup_Map.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_Map.svg/880px-2014_FIFA_World_Cup_Map.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="842" data-file-height="362" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:2014_FIFA_World_Cup_Map.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Result of countries participating in the 2014 FIFA World Cup
