<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Preparations_and_costs">Preparations and costs</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_preparations" title="2014 FIFA World Cup preparations">2014 FIFA World Cup preparations</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Abschlussfeier_Maracana_Fifa_WM_2014_(14691639602).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Abschlussfeier_Maracana_Fifa_WM_2014_%2814691639602%29.jpg/220px-Abschlussfeier_Maracana_Fifa_WM_2014_%2814691639602%29.jpg" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Abschlussfeier_Maracana_Fifa_WM_2014_%2814691639602%29.jpg/330px-Abschlussfeier_Maracana_Fifa_WM_2014_%2814691639602%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Abschlussfeier_Maracana_Fifa_WM_2014_%2814691639602%29.jpg/440px-Abschlussfeier_Maracana_Fifa_WM_2014_%2814691639602%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4288" data-file-height="2848" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Abschlussfeier_Maracana_Fifa_WM_2014_(14691639602).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Inauguration program</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Forecasts on the eve of the tournament estimated that the cost to the Brazilian government would be US$14&#160;billion, making it the most expensive World Cup to date.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[101]</a></sup> FIFA is expected to spend US$2&#160;billion on staging the finals,<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[102]</a></sup> with its greatest single expense being the <a href="#Prize_money">US$576&#160;million prize money pot</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_105-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-105">[99]</a></sup></p>
<p>Although organisers originally estimated costs of US$1.1&#160;billion,<sup id="cite_ref-Inspection_report_109-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Inspection_report-109">[103]</a></sup> a reported US$3.6&#160;billion was ultimately spent on stadium works.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[104]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[105]</a></sup> Five of the chosen host cities had brand new venues built specifically for the World Cup, while the <a href="/wiki/Est%C3%A1dio_Nacional_Man%C3%A9_Garrincha" title="Estádio Nacional Mané Garrincha">Estádio Nacional Mané Garrincha</a> in the capital <a href="/wiki/Bras%C3%ADlia" title="Brasília">Brasília</a> was demolished and rebuilt, with the remaining six being extensively renovated.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[106]</a></sup></p>
<p>An additional R$3&#160;billion (US$1.3&#160;billion, €960&#160;million, £780&#160;million at June 2014 rates) was earmarked by the Brazilian government for investment in infrastructure works and projects for use during the 2014 World Cup and beyond.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[107]</a></sup> However, the failed completion of many of the proposed works provoked discontent among some Brazilians.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[108]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[109]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[110]</a></sup></p>
<p>The Brazilian government pledged US$900&#160;million to be invested into security forces and that the tournament would be "one of the most protected sports events in history."<sup id="cite_ref-CNN_117-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CNN-117">[111]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Marketing">Marketing</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:212px;"><a href="/wiki/File:FulecoMascot.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/3/30/FulecoMascot.jpg" width="210" height="230" class="thumbimage" data-file-width="210" data-file-height="230" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:FulecoMascot.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Fuleco" title="Fuleco">Fuleco</a>, the official mascot of the 2014 FIFA World Cup</div>
</div>
</div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_marketing" title="2014 FIFA World Cup marketing">2014 FIFA World Cup marketing</a></div>
<p>The marketing of the 2014 FIFA World Cup included sale of tickets, support from sponsors and promotion through events that utilise the symbols and <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_official_songs" title="FIFA World Cup official songs">songs</a> of the tournament. Popular merchandise included items featuring the <a href="/wiki/Fuleco" title="Fuleco">official mascot</a> as well as an <a href="/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_Brazil_(video_game)" title="2014 FIFA World Cup Brazil (video game)">official video game</a> that has been developed by <a href="/wiki/EA_Sports" title="EA Sports">EA Sports</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-videogame1_118-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-videogame1-118">[112]</a></sup> The official song of the tournament was "<a href="/wiki/We_Are_One_(Ole_Ola)" title="We Are One (Ole Ola)">We Are One (Ole Ola)</a>" with vocals from <a href="/wiki/Pitbull_(rapper)" title="Pitbull (rapper)">Pitbull</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jennifer_Lopez" title="Jennifer Lopez">Jennifer Lopez</a> and <a href="/wiki/Claudia_Leitte" title="Claudia Leitte">Claudia Leitte</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[113]</a></sup> As a partner of the <a href="/wiki/German_Football_Association" title="German Football Association">German Football Association</a>, the German airline <a href="/wiki/Lufthansa" title="Lufthansa">Lufthansa</a> renamed itself "Fanhansa" on some of its planes that flew the German national team, media representatives and football fans to Brazil.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[114]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">See also: <a href="/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_broadcasting_rights" title="2014 FIFA World Cup broadcasting rights">2014 FIFA World Cup broadcasting rights</a></div>
<p>For a fourth consecutive FIFA World Cup Finals, the coverage was provided by HBS (Host Broadcast Services), a subsidiary of <a href="/wiki/Infront_Sports_%26_Media" title="Infront Sports &amp; Media">Infront Sports &amp; Media</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[115]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sony" title="Sony">Sony</a> was selected as the official equipment provider and built 12 bespoke <a href="/wiki/High-definition_video" title="High-definition video">high definition</a> production 40-foot-long containers, one for each tournament venue, to house the extensive amount of equipment required.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[116]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-redsharknews1_123-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-redsharknews1-123">[117]</a></sup> Each match utilised 37 standard camera plans, including Aerial and Cablecam, two Ultramotion cameras and dedicated cameras for interviews.<sup id="cite_ref-redsharknews1_123-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-redsharknews1-123">[117]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/List_of_official_FIFA_World_Cup_films" title="List of official FIFA World Cup films">The official tournament film</a>, as well as three matches,<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[nb 7]</a></sup> will be filmed with <a href="/wiki/Ultra_high_definition_television" class="mw-redirect" title="Ultra high definition television">ultra high definition</a> technology (<a href="/wiki/4K_resolution" title="4K resolution">4K resolution</a>), following a successful trial at the <a href="/wiki/2013_FIFA_Confederations_Cup" title="2013 FIFA Confederations Cup">2013 FIFA Confederations Cup</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[118]</a></sup></p>
<p>The broadcasting rights&#160;– covering television, radio, internet and mobile coverage&#160;– for the tournament were sold to media companies in each individual territory either directly by FIFA, or through licensed companies or organisations such as the <a href="/wiki/European_Broadcasting_Union" title="European Broadcasting Union">European Broadcasting Union</a>, <a href="/wiki/Organizaci%C3%B3n_de_Televisi%C3%B3n_Iberoamericana" class="mw-redirect" title="Organización de Televisión Iberoamericana">Organización de Televisión Iberoamericana</a>, International Media Content, <a href="/wiki/Dentsu" title="Dentsu">Dentsu</a> and RS International Broadcasting &amp; Sports Management.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[119]</a></sup> The sale of these rights accounted for an estimated 60% of FIFA's income from staging a World Cup.<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[120]</a></sup> The International Broadcast Centre was situated at the <a href="/wiki/Riocentro" title="Riocentro">Riocentro</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Barra_da_Tijuca,_Rio_de_Janeiro" class="mw-redirect" title="Barra da Tijuca, Rio de Janeiro">Barra da Tijuca</a> neighbourhood of Rio de Janeiro.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[121]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[122]</a></sup></p>
<p>Worldwide, several games qualified as the most-watched sporting events in their country in 2014, including 42.9 million people in Brazil for the opening game between Brazil and Croatia, the 34.1 million in Japan who saw their team play Ivory Coast, and 34.7 million in Germany who saw their national team win the World Cup against Argentina,<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[123]</a></sup> while the 24.7 million viewers during the game between the USA and Portugal is joint with the 2010 final as the most-watched football game in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">[124]</a></sup> According to FIFA, over one billion people tuned in worldwide to watch <a href="/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_Final" title="2014 FIFA World Cup Final">the final</a> between Germany and Argentina.<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[125]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Controversies">Controversies</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/List_of_2014_FIFA_World_Cup_controversies" title="List of 2014 FIFA World Cup controversies">List of 2014 FIFA World Cup controversies</a></div>
<p>The 2014 FIFA World Cup generated various controversies, including demonstrations, some of which took place even before the tournament started. Furthermore, there were various issues with safety, including eight deaths of workers and a fire during construction, breaches into stadiums, an unstable makeshift staircase at the <a href="/wiki/Maracan%C3%A3_Stadium" title="Maracanã Stadium">Maracanã Stadium</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Monorail" title="Monorail">monorail</a> collapse, and the <a href="/wiki/Belo_Horizonte_overpass_collapse" title="Belo Horizonte overpass collapse">collapse of an unfinished overpass</a> in <a href="/wiki/Belo_Horizonte" title="Belo Horizonte">Belo Horizonte</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[126]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[127]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[128]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[129]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Monorail_collapses_BBC_137-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Monorail_collapses_BBC-137">[130]</a></sup> The houses of thousands of families in <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a> were cleared for redevelopments for the World Cup in spite of protests and resistance. Favela do Metrô, near the Maracanã Stadium, was completely destroyed as a result, having previously housed 700 families in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[131]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[132]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[133]</a></sup></p>
<p>In the tournament itself, controversy centred around <a href="/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_officials" title="2014 FIFA World Cup officials">officiating</a>, with international <a href="/wiki/Referee_(association_football)" title="Referee (association football)">referees</a> including <a href="/wiki/Yuichi_Nishimura" title="Yuichi Nishimura">Yuichi Nishimura</a>, <a href="/wiki/Milorad_Ma%C5%BEi%C4%87" title="Milorad Mažić">Milorad Mažić</a>, <a href="/wiki/Enrique_Osses" title="Enrique Osses">Enrique Osses</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peter_O%27Leary_(referee)" title="Peter O'Leary (referee)">Peter O'Leary</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ravshan_Irmatov" title="Ravshan Irmatov">Ravshan Irmatov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Howard_Webb" title="Howard Webb">Howard Webb</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mark_Geiger" title="Mark Geiger">Mark Geiger</a>, <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Velasco_Carballo" title="Carlos Velasco Carballo">Carlos Velasco Carballo</a>, and assistant Humberto Clavijo coming under criticism for their performances. The most notable disciplinary case was that of Uruguayan striker <a href="/wiki/Luis_Su%C3%A1rez" title="Luis Suárez">Luis Suárez</a>, who was disciplined after <a href="/wiki/List_of_2014_FIFA_World_Cup_controversies#Uruguay_vs_Italy" title="List of 2014 FIFA World Cup controversies">biting Italian player</a> <a href="/wiki/Giorgio_Chiellini" title="Giorgio Chiellini">Giorgio Chiellini</a> during the game between <a href="/wiki/Italy_national_football_team" title="Italy national football team">Italy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Uruguay_national_football_team" title="Uruguay national football team">Uruguay</a>.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Protests">Protests</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Protest_against_the_World_Cup_in_Copacabana_(2014-06-12)_12.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Protest_against_the_World_Cup_in_Copacabana_%282014-06-12%29_12.jpg/220px-Protest_against_the_World_Cup_in_Copacabana_%282014-06-12%29_12.jpg" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Protest_against_the_World_Cup_in_Copacabana_%282014-06-12%29_12.jpg/330px-Protest_against_the_World_Cup_in_Copacabana_%282014-06-12%29_12.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Protest_against_the_World_Cup_in_Copacabana_%282014-06-12%29_12.jpg/440px-Protest_against_the_World_Cup_in_Copacabana_%282014-06-12%29_12.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4928" data-file-height="3264" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Protest_against_the_World_Cup_in_Copacabana_(2014-06-12)_12.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Anti-World Cup demonstration on the opening day.</div>
</div>
</div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Further information: <a href="/wiki/List_of_2014_FIFA_World_Cup_controversies#Protests" title="List of 2014 FIFA World Cup controversies">List of 2014 FIFA World Cup controversies §&#160;Protests</a></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">See also: <a href="/wiki/2013_protests_in_Brazil" title="2013 protests in Brazil">2013 protests in Brazil</a> and <a href="/wiki/2014_protests_in_Brazil" title="2014 protests in Brazil">2014 protests in Brazil</a></div>
<p>Prior to the opening ceremony of the <a href="/wiki/2013_FIFA_Confederations_Cup" title="2013 FIFA Confederations Cup">2013 FIFA Confederations Cup</a> staged in Brazil, demonstrations took place outside <a href="/wiki/Est%C3%A1dio_Nacional_Man%C3%A9_Garrincha" title="Estádio Nacional Mané Garrincha">the venue</a>, organised by people unhappy with the amount of public money spent to enable the hosting of the FIFA World Cup.<sup id="cite_ref-Confederations_Cup_opening_protests_141-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Confederations_Cup_opening_protests-141">[134]</a></sup> Both the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Brazil" title="President of Brazil">Brazilian president</a> <a href="/wiki/Dilma_Rousseff" title="Dilma Rousseff">Dilma Rousseff</a> and FIFA president <a href="/wiki/Sepp_Blatter" title="Sepp Blatter">Sepp Blatter</a> were heavily booed as they were announced to give their speeches at the 2013 tournament's opening,<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[135]</a></sup> which resulted in FIFA announcing that the <a href="/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_opening_ceremony" title="2014 FIFA World Cup opening ceremony">2014 FIFA World Cup opening ceremony</a> would not feature any speeches.<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[136]</a></sup> Further protests took place during the Confederations Cup as well as prior to and during the World Cup.<sup id="cite_ref-Confederations_Cup_protests1_144-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Confederations_Cup_protests1-144">[137]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Confederations_Cup_protests2_145-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Confederations_Cup_protests2-145">[138]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-World_Cup_protests1_146-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-World_Cup_protests1-146">[139]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-World_Cup_protests2_147-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-World_Cup_protests2-147">[140]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-World_Cup_protests3_148-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-World_Cup_protests3-148">[141]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Breaches_into_stadiums">Breaches into stadiums</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Further information: <a href="/wiki/List_of_2014_FIFA_World_Cup_controversies#Breaches_into_stadiums" title="List of 2014 FIFA World Cup controversies">List of 2014 FIFA World Cup controversies §&#160;Breaches into stadiums</a></div>
<p>At the <a href="/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_B#Spain_vs_Chile" title="2014 FIFA World Cup Group B">Group B match</a> between <a href="/wiki/Spain_national_football_team" title="Spain national football team">Spain</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chile_national_football_team" title="Chile national football team">Chile</a>, around 100 Chilean supporters who had gathered outside <a href="/wiki/Maracan%C3%A3_Stadium" title="Maracanã Stadium">Maracanã Stadium</a> forced their way into the stadium and caused damage to the media centre. Military police reported that 85 Chileans were detained during the events, while others reached the stands. Earlier, about 20 Argentinians made a similar breach during Argentina's <a href="/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_F#Argentina_vs_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina" title="2014 FIFA World Cup Group F">Group F game</a> against Bosnia and Herzegovina at the same stadium.<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[142]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[143]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Bridge_collapse">Bridge collapse</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Belo_Horizonte_overpass_collapse" title="Belo Horizonte overpass collapse">Belo Horizonte overpass collapse</a></div>
<p>On 3 July 2014, an <a href="/wiki/Overpass" title="Overpass">overpass</a> under construction in <a href="/wiki/Belo_Horizonte" title="Belo Horizonte">Belo Horizonte</a> as part of the World Cup <a href="/wiki/Infrastructure" title="Infrastructure">infrastructure</a> projects collapsed onto a busy <a href="/wiki/Carriageway" title="Carriageway">carriageway</a> below, leaving two people dead and 22 others injured.<sup id="cite_ref-Overpass_collapses_BBC_151-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Overpass_collapses_BBC-151">[144]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Overpass_collapses_Reuters_152-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Overpass_collapses_Reuters-152">[145]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Head_injuries">Head injuries</span></h3>
<p>During the tournament, FIFA received significant criticism for the way head injuries are handled during matches. Two incidents in particular attracted the most attention. First, in a group stage match, after Uruguayan defender <a href="/wiki/%C3%81lvaro_Pereira" title="Álvaro Pereira">Álvaro Pereira</a> received a blow to the head, he lay unconscious.<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[146]</a></sup> The Uruguayan doctor signaled for the player to be substituted, but he returned to the match. The incident drew criticism from the professional players' union FIFPro, and from Michel D'Hooghe, a member of the FIFA executive board and chairman of its medical committee.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[147]</a></sup></p>
<p>Second, in the Final, German midfielder <a href="/wiki/Christoph_Kramer" title="Christoph Kramer">Christoph Kramer</a> received a blow to the head from a collision in the 14th minute, but returned to the match before collapsing in the 31st minute. During that time, Kramer was disoriented and confused, and asked the referee <a href="/wiki/Nicola_Rizzoli" title="Nicola Rizzoli">Nicola Rizzoli</a> whether the match he was playing in was the World Cup Final.<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[148]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/2015_FIFA_Women%27s_World_Cup" title="2015 FIFA Women's World Cup">2015 FIFA Women's World Cup</a></li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;">
<ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-1">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_Portuguese" title="Brazilian Portuguese">Brazilian Portuguese</a> pronunciation is <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA_for_Portuguese" title="Help:IPA for Portuguese">[ˈkɔpɐ du ˈmũdu da ˈfifɐ bɾaˈziw ˈdojz ˈmiw i kaˈtoʁzi]</a></span>, in Brazil's standard pronunciation.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-18"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-18">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Bosnia and Herzegovina was until 1992 part of Yugoslavia, which competed at eight World Cup tournaments.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-35"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-35">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The <a href="/wiki/Itaipava_Arena_Pernambuco" title="Itaipava Arena Pernambuco">Itaipava Arena Pernambuco</a> is located in <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Louren%C3%A7o_da_Mata" title="São Lourenço da Mata">São Lourenço da Mata</a>, <a href="/wiki/Recife_metropolitan_area" title="Recife metropolitan area">Recife metropolitan area</a>.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-45"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-45">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The spray was trialled at the <a href="/wiki/2013_FIFA_U-20_World_Cup" title="2013 FIFA U-20 World Cup">2013 FIFA U-20 World Cup</a>, <a href="/wiki/2013_FIFA_U-17_World_Cup" title="2013 FIFA U-17 World Cup">2013 FIFA U-17 World Cup</a> and <a href="/wiki/2013_FIFA_Club_World_Cup" title="2013 FIFA Club World Cup">2013 FIFA Club World Cup</a></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-69"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-69">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">This is the time zone of ten of the twelve venues; the other two, <a href="/wiki/Cuiab%C3%A1" title="Cuiabá">Cuiabá</a> and <a href="/wiki/Manaus" title="Manaus">Manaus</a>, are in the <a href="/wiki/Time_in_Brazil#Bras.C3.ADlia_time_.E2.88.92_1_.28UTC-04.29" title="Time in Brazil">Amazon time zone</a> (<a href="/wiki/UTC%E2%88%9204:00" title="UTC−04:00">UTC−4</a>), therefore for matches hosted at these two venues the local kickoff times are one hour earlier than the times listed.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[62]</a></sup> The match schedule was announced at FIFA's headquarters in <a href="/wiki/Z%C3%BCrich" title="Zürich">Zürich</a> on 20 October 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[63]</a></sup> After the final draw, the kick-off times of seven matches were adjusted by FIFA.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[64]</a></sup></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-79"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-79">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">In <a href="/wiki/1938_FIFA_World_Cup#First_round" title="1938 FIFA World Cup">1938's round of 16</a>, two games were also tied after extra-time, but those were <a href="/wiki/Replay_(sports)" title="Replay (sports)">replayed</a> instead.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-124"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-124">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Those matches scheduled to be filmed in ultra high definition were one match from the round of 16 (on 28 June), one quarter-final (on 4 July) and the final</span></li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2>

CNN. 12 June 2014.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3A2014+FIFA+World+Cup&amp;rft.atitle=Brazilian+police+fire+tear+gas+at+World+Cup+protesters%3B+CNN+employees+injured+by+anti-riot+weapons&amp;rft.date=2014-06-12&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fedition.cnn.com%2F2014%2F06%2F12%2Fworld%2Famericas%2Fbrazil-world-cup-protests%2F&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>

<li id="cite_note-150"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-150">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation news"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-06-18/world-cup-chile-fans-storm-rio-stadium-ahead-of-spain-game.html">"World Cup Chile Fans Storm Rio Stadium And 85 Detained"</a>. <i>Bloomberg</i>. 19 June 2014.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3A2014+FIFA+World+Cup&amp;rft.atitle=World+Cup+Chile+Fans+Storm+Rio+Stadium+And+85+Detained&amp;rft.date=2014-06-19&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.bloomberg.com%2Fnews%2F2014-06-18%2Fworld-cup-chile-fans-storm-rio-stadium-ahead-of-spain-game.html&amp;rft.jtitle=Bloomberg&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>

<td class="navbox-abovebelow" colspan="2" style="background:gold;">
<div>Notes: There was no qualification for the 1930 World Cup as places were given by invitation only. In 1950, there was no final; the article is about the decisive match of the final group stage.</div>
